At 23:49 26/08/2004, you wrote:
>Colin Green wrote:
>
> >hmm, so genes that are close together tend to be functionaly dependent.
> >Genotype proximity indicates phenotype proximity. Whereas in NEAT the
> >genes always remain in the order they were added to the genome (this
> >makes comparison nice and fast), but perhaps we are loosing some
> >important properties by doing this - namely, crossover could be allowed
> >to re-arrange genes into functionaly dependent groups. Hey I like this
> >idea a lot Ian.
> >
> >
>I just had another idea. If I remember correctly, in nature genes are
>usually marked out with certain short sequences of DNA. Perhaps we could
>introduce the concept of a marker gene into the NEAT genome. We could
>then implement a multipoint crossover technique that is marker aware and
>hopefully genes would become re-ordered into functionaly dependent
>groups far more efficiently than using plain old random multipoint
>crossover.
>
>Of course I am assuming that nature uses the markers during crossover as
>well as during expression of the genes. Actually it might not matter, if
>crossover ignores the markers then the genes will still form functional
>groups during expression. There may be a great deal of junk either side
>of the markers if crossover is ignoring them - but then there is all
>that 'junk' DNA isn't there.


I guess you are talking about the common, short repetitive sequences found 
in the Junk DNA?

They are not used as labels.  It's purely position on the chromosome and 
homology between the two chromosomes which determines their alignment 
before crossover (they are physically lined-up next to each other).  There 
is (used to be) some talk that repetitive sequences increase the 
probability of sequence duplication (which happens by misaligning the 
chromosomes before crossover, and leads to one output with two copies of a 
section, and one with none).

You can easily reason that repetitive sequences create themselves in this 
way, in a "selfish DNA" manner, without affecting the individuals fitness.

--

Don't let that stop you, however, we don't need to take every idea from nature.

--

What you are describing is what I call an Arbitrary Label System 
(ALS).  It's part of a body of proposed research that I am slowly writing 
up as a position document.  I will announce the document here when I get it 
done.  (I'm not claiming to have invented the idea, I don't know where I 
got it from.)

An ALS works as follows:

1) some sort of "entities" (genes, networks, channels) have labels
2) labels are subject to mutation along with the rest of the genome
3) connections between entities are established using label compatibility

That's deliberately vague, because the idea has several applications.  The 
broad idea is that label values co-evolve with the content of the entities 
they are attached to.  The labels thus provide the "weak binding" required 
for evolvability (in one body of theory, at least).

For example, to support modular neat:

1) use multiple (different) networks in the individual -- code each network 
on a different "chromosome"
2) label each input to the individual
3) label each input to a network
4) label each output from the individual
5) label each output from a network

When the individual is instantiated, bind each input to the output with the 
most-closely matching label.

Thus, for example, if one of the networks evolves as (say) a feature 
extractor, then it will also evolve a label which will come to mean 
"feature extractor #1".  Chromosome duplication can add a second copy of 
the same feature extractor.  Initially it binds the same, is labelled the 
same, and functions the same.  Labels (and thus bindings) and function can 
now drift between the two copies, until we have a different feature 
extractor, with a label meaning "feature extractor #2".

My list of uses for ALS is:

1) label the individuals inputs and outputs (as above)
2) label connection points in a multi-component phenotype (needs #1, also 
as above)
3) gene labels for crossover (your point)
4) labels on working data stored in an individual (networks _can_ store 
data internally, but I don't plan to only use ANN)
5) label individuals to define relatedness for crossover

--

An ALS might have features:

Matching by similarity, or, matching by complementarity (A matches A vs A 
matches ~A).

Labels are split into "sockets" and "pugs" or all labels bind one another.

Labels optionally also carry a "specificity" parameter determining how 
close a match must be.

Label values can be single numbers, character sequences, vectors, sets...

         Ian
